Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: An individual arrived at the mosque in visible distress, seeking immediate spiritual counsel to cope with a major loss.
Story: I was finishing up a trim for Mrs. Rahman, my favorite regular, when she glanced in the mirror and smiled. “Could you just take a little more off the fringe?” she asked, her tone gentle. I nodded, reaching for my scissors, determined to make sure she left happy—client satisfaction was everything in my shop. Just then, my phone buzzed urgently. It was a message from the mosque: a young man had arrived, devastated by the sudden loss of his father, and was asking for me. As the imam, I knew my presence was needed immediately to offer comfort and guidance. My heart pounded as I looked at Mrs. Rahman, waiting patiently, trusting me to finish her hair just right. At the same time, I pictured the young man, alone and desperate for spiritual support. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding my full attention, each expecting me to be present, calm, and caring. I stood there, scissors in hand, torn between two worlds, unsure which need to answer first.
